mn29:0.2.eng: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

mn29:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate acirapakkante devadatte.
mn29:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left.
mn29:1.2.comm: Devadatta was the Buddha’s cousin and nemesis. After going forth together with several other relatives of the Buddha (Kd 17:1.4.1), his initial success in meditation was corrupted by his desire for gains and fame (SN 17.35). He tried to take over the Saṅgha but was denounced by the Buddha. His attempt to create a schismatic faction failed and he died in disgrace.

mn29:1.3.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā devadattaṃ ārabbha bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn29:1.3.eng: There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:

mn29:2.1.pli: “Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti:
mn29:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, take the case of a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking,

mn29:2.2.pli: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto,
mn29:2.2.eng: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

mn29:2.3.pli: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
mn29:2.3.eng: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’

mn29:2.4.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno lābhasakkārasilokaṃ abhinibbatteti.
mn29:2.4.eng: When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity.

mn29:2.5.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
mn29:2.5.eng: They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for.

mn29:2.6.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena attānukkaṃseti paraṃ vambheti:
mn29:2.6.eng: And they glorify themselves and put others down because of that:

mn29:2.7.pli: ‘ahamasmi lābhasakkārasilokavā, ime panaññe bhikkhū appaññātā appesakkhā’ti.
mn29:2.7.eng: ‘I’m the one with possessions, honor, and popularity. These other mendicants are obscure and insignificant.’

mn29:2.8.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena majjati pamajjati pamādaṃ āpajjati, pamatto samāno dukkhaṃ viharati.
mn29:2.8.eng: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence on account of those possessions, honor, and popularity. And being negligent they live in suffering.
mn29:2.8.comm: The Chinese parallel at EA 43.4 says that this discourse was given during the time he was being lavishly supported by Prince Ajātasattu (SN 17.36, Kd 17:2.1.1).

mn29:2.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṃ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato atikkammeva sāraṃ atikkamma phegguṃ atikkamma tacaṃ atikkamma papaṭikaṃ, sākhāpalāsaṃ chetvā ādāya pakkameyya ‘sāran’ti maññamāno.
mn29:2.9.eng: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood, softwood, bark, and shoots, he’d cut off the branches and leaves and leave imagining they were heartwood.
mn29:2.9.comm: Compare the “noble quest” on MN 26 and the search for a “bull elephant” in MN 27. In each case the metaphor emphasizes the specific and uncompromising nature of the goal. The moral is to not stop until the journey is truly complete.

mn29:2.10.pli: Tamenaṃ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṃ vadeyya:
mn29:2.10.eng: If a person with clear eyes saw him they’d say,

mn29:2.11.pli: ‘na vatāyaṃ bhavaṃ puriso aññāsi sāraṃ, na aññāsi phegguṃ, na aññāsi tacaṃ, na aññāsi papaṭikaṃ, na aññāsi sākhāpalāsaṃ.
mn29:2.11.eng: ‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are.

mn29:2.12.pli: Tathā hayaṃ bhavaṃ puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṃ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato atikkammeva sāraṃ atikkamma phegguṃ atikkamma tacaṃ atikkamma papaṭikaṃ, sākhāpalāsaṃ chetvā ādāya pakkanto “sāran”ti maññamāno.
mn29:2.12.eng: That’s why he passed them over, cut off the branches and leaves, and left imagining they were heartwood.

mn29:2.13.pli: Yañcassa sārena sārakaraṇīyaṃ tañcassa atthaṃ nānubhavissatī’ti.
mn29:2.13.eng: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …

mn29:2.14.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti:

mn29:2.15.pli: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto,

mn29:2.16.pli: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.

mn29:2.17.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno lābhasakkārasilokaṃ abhinibbatteti.

mn29:2.18.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.

mn29:2.19.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena attānukkaṃseti, paraṃ vambheti ‘ahamasmi lābhasakkārasilokavā, ime panaññe bhikkhū appaññātā appesakkhā’ti.

mn29:2.20.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena majjati pamajjati pamādaṃ āpajjati, pamatto samāno dukkhaṃ viharati.

mn29:2.21.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sākhāpalāsaṃ aggahesi brahmacariyassa;
mn29:2.21.eng: This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the branches and leaves of the spiritual life

mn29:3.5.eng: They’re not happy with that, and haven’t got all they wished for.

mn29:3.7.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṃ āpajjati.
mn29:3.7.eng: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence on account of those possessions, honor, and popularity.

mn29:3.8.eng: Being diligent, they achieve accomplishment in ethics.

mn29:3.9.pli: So tāya sīlasampadāya attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
mn29:3.9.eng: They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for.

mn29:3.10.pli: So tāya sīlasampadāya attānukkaṃseti, paraṃ vambheti:
mn29:3.10.eng: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that:

mn29:3.11.pli: ‘ahamasmi sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo, ime panaññe bhikkhū dussīlā pāpadhammā’ti.
mn29:3.11.eng: ‘I’m the one who is ethical, of good character. These other mendicants are unethical, of bad character.’

mn29:3.12.pli: So tāya sīlasampadāya majjati pamajjati pamādaṃ āpajjati, pamatto samāno dukkhaṃ viharati.
mn29:3.12.eng: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding their accomplishment in ethics. And being negligent they live in suffering.

mn29:5.14.pli: So tāya samādhisampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṃ āpajjati appamatto samāno ñāṇadassanaṃ ārādheti.
mn29:5.14.eng: Being diligent, they achieve knowledge and vision.
mn29:5.14.comm: While “knowledge and vision” (ñāṇadassana) that is “in accordance with reality” (yathābhūta) refers to the vision of the four noble truths at stream-entry, “knowledge and vision” by itself does not have a well established technical meaning. At DN 2:83.1 it is said to be a vision of the body with its consciousness, although this passage is rare and in MN 77:29.11 is not described as “knowledge and vision”. Elsewhere it is used in a variety of senses for a kind of clear and enhanced spiritual understanding.

mn29:5.22.eng: ‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are.

mn29:5.23.pli: Tathā hayaṃ bhavaṃ puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṃ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato atikkammeva sāraṃ phegguṃ chetvā ādāya pakkanto “sāran”ti maññamāno.
mn29:5.23.eng: That’s why he passed them over, cut out the softwood, and left imagining it was heartwood.

mn29:5.24.pli: Yañcassa sārena sārakaraṇīyaṃ tañcassa atthaṃ nānubhavissatī’ti.
mn29:5.24.eng: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …

mn29:5.25.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti:

mn29:5.26.pli: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto,

mn29:5.27.pli: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.

mn29:5.28.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno lābhasakkārasilokaṃ abhinibbatteti.

mn29:5.29.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attamano hoti na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.

mn29:5.30.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attānukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti.

mn29:5.31.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṃ āpajjati, appamatto samāno sīlasampadaṃ ārādheti.

mn29:5.32.pli: So tāya sīlasampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.

mn29:5.33.pli: So tāya sīlasampadāya na attānukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti.

mn29:5.34.pli: So tāya sīlasampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṃ āpajjati, appamatto samāno samādhisampadaṃ ārādheti.

mn29:5.35.pli: So tāya samādhisampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.

mn29:5.36.pli: So tāya samādhisampadāya na attānukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti.

mn29:5.37.pli: So tāya samādhisampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṃ āpajjati, appamatto samāno ñāṇadassanaṃ ārādheti.

mn29:5.38.pli: So tena ñāṇadassanena attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.

mn29:5.39.pli: So tena ñāṇadassanena attānukkaṃseti, paraṃ vambheti:

mn29:5.40.pli: ‘ahamasmi jānaṃ passaṃ viharāmi, ime panaññe bhikkhū ajānaṃ apassaṃ viharantī’ti.

mn29:5.41.pli: So tena ñāṇadassanena majjati pamajjati pamādaṃ āpajjati, pamatto samāno dukkhaṃ viharati.

mn29:5.42.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu phegguṃ aggahesi brahmacariyassa;
mn29:5.42.eng: This is called a mendicant who has grabbed the softwood of the spiritual life

mn29:6.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti:
mn29:6.1.eng: Next, take a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking,

mn29:6.2.pli: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto,
mn29:6.2.eng: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

mn29:6.3.pli: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
mn29:6.3.eng: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’

mn29:6.4.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno lābhasakkārasilokaṃ abhinibbatteti.
mn29:6.4.eng: When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity.

mn29:6.5.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attamano hoti, na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
mn29:6.5.eng: They’re not happy with that, and haven’t got all they wished for.

mn29:6.6.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attānukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti.
mn29:6.6.eng: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.

mn29:6.7.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṃ āpajjati, appamatto samāno sīlasampadaṃ ārādheti.
mn29:6.7.eng: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence on account of those possessions, honor, and popularity. Being diligent, they achieve accomplishment in ethics.

mn29:6.8.pli: So tāya sīlasampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
mn29:6.8.eng: They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for.

mn29:6.9.pli: So tāya sīlasampadāya na attānukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti.
mn29:6.9.eng: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.

mn29:6.10.pli: So tāya sīlasampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṃ āpajjati, appamatto samāno samādhisampadaṃ ārādheti.
mn29:6.10.eng: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that accomplishment in ethics. Being diligent, they achieve accomplishment in immersion.

mn29:6.11.pli: So tāya samādhisampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
mn29:6.11.eng: They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for.

mn29:6.12.pli: So tāya samādhisampadāya na attānukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti.
mn29:6.12.eng: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.

mn29:6.13.pli: So tāya samādhisampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṃ āpajjati, appamatto samāno ñāṇadassanaṃ ārādheti.
mn29:6.13.eng: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that accomplishment in immersion. Being diligent, they achieve knowledge and vision.

mn29:6.14.pli: So tena ñāṇadassanena attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.
mn29:6.14.eng: They’re happy with that, but they haven’t got all they wished for.

mn29:6.15.pli: So tena ñāṇadassanena na attānukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti.
mn29:6.15.eng: They don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.

mn29:6.16.pli: So tena ñāṇadassanena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṃ āpajjati, appamatto samāno asamayavimokkhaṃ ārādheti.
mn29:6.16.eng: Nor do they become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that knowledge and vision. Being diligent, they achieve irreversible freedom.
mn29:6.16.comm: The “irreversible freedom” (asamaya, literally “not temporary”) is that of arahantship, as opposed to the “temporary freedom” of samādhi, from which one can fall away due to bad conduct (AN 5.149), like Devadatta. | Text inconsistently has vimokkha (“liberation”) here and vimutti (“freedom”) in the next line, although elsewhere the suttas always read vimutti. It seems that when these attainments came to be included in the Vimokkha Chapter of the Paṭisambhidāmagga (a late canonical Abhidhamma-style text), they were renamed vimokkha to fit the context (Ps 1.5:2.10). The commentary then cited that passage here using vimokkha, but the commentarial gloss must have contaminated the text. I translate under the assumption that the correct reading is vimutti, although it makes no practical difference.

mn29:6.17.pli: Aṭṭhānametaṃ, bhikkhave, anavakāso yaṃ so bhikkhu tāya asamayavimuttiyā parihāyetha.
mn29:6.17.eng: And it’s impossible for that mendicant to fall away from that irreversible freedom.

mn29:6.18.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṃ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato sāraññeva chetvā ādāya pakkameyya ‘sāran’ti jānamāno.
mn29:6.18.eng: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. He’d cut out just the heartwood and leave knowing it was heartwood.

mn29:6.19.pli: Tamenaṃ cakkhumā puriso disvā evaṃ vadeyya:
mn29:6.19.eng: If a person with clear eyes saw him they’d say,

mn29:6.20.pli: ‘aññāsi vatāyaṃ bhavaṃ puriso sāraṃ, aññāsi phegguṃ, aññāsi tacaṃ, aññāsi papaṭikaṃ, aññāsi sākhāpalāsaṃ.
mn29:6.20.eng: ‘This gentleman knows what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, and branches and leaves are.

mn29:6.21.pli: Tathā hayaṃ bhavaṃ puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṃ caramāno mahato rukkhassa tiṭṭhato sāravato sāraññeva chetvā ādāya pakkanto “sāran”ti jānamāno.
mn29:6.21.eng: That’s why he cut out just the heartwood and left knowing it was heartwood.

mn29:6.22.pli: Yañcassa sārena sārakaraṇīyaṃ tañcassa atthaṃ anubhavissatī’ti.
mn29:6.22.eng: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he will succeed.’ …

mn29:6.23.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti:

mn29:6.24.pli: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto,

mn29:6.25.pli: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.

mn29:6.26.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno lābhasakkārasilokaṃ abhinibbatteti.

mn29:6.27.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attamano hoti, na paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.

mn29:6.28.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na attānukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti.

mn29:6.29.pli: So tena lābhasakkārasilokena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṃ āpajjati, appamatto samāno sīlasampadaṃ ārādheti.

mn29:6.30.pli: So tāya sīlasampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.

mn29:6.31.pli: So tāya sīlasampadāya na attānukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti.

mn29:6.32.pli: So tāya sīlasampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṃ āpajjati, appamatto samāno samādhisampadaṃ ārādheti.

mn29:6.33.pli: So tāya samādhisampadāya attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.

mn29:6.34.pli: So tāya samādhisampadāya na attānukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti.

mn29:6.35.pli: So tāya samādhisampadāya na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṃ āpajjati, appamatto samāno ñāṇadassanaṃ ārādheti.

mn29:6.36.pli: So tena ñāṇadassanena attamano hoti, no ca kho paripuṇṇasaṅkappo.

mn29:6.37.pli: So tena ñāṇadassanena na attānukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti.

mn29:6.38.pli: So tena ñāṇadassanena na majjati nappamajjati na pamādaṃ āpajjati, appamatto samāno asamayavimokkhaṃ ārādheti.

mn29:6.39.pli: Aṭṭhānametaṃ, bhikkhave, anavakāso yaṃ so bhikkhu tāya asamayavimuttiyā parihāyetha.
mn29:6.39.eng: It’s impossible for that mendicant to fall away from that irreversible freedom.

mn29:7.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, nayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ lābhasakkārasilokānisaṃsaṃ, na sīlasampadānisaṃsaṃ, na samādhisampadānisaṃsaṃ, na ñāṇadassanānisaṃsaṃ.
mn29:7.1.eng: And so, mendicants, this spiritual life is not lived for the sake of possessions, honor, and popularity, or for accomplishment in ethics, or for accomplishment in immersion, or for knowledge and vision.

mn29:7.2.pli: Yā ca kho ayaṃ, bhikkhave, akuppā cetovimutti—
mn29:7.2.eng: It is this unshakable freedom of heart
mn29:7.2.comm: This links the “irreversible” freedom with the “unshakable” freedom of arahantship; the two are equated at MN 122:4.1.

mn29:7.3.pli: etadatthamidaṃ, bhikkhave, brahmacariyaṃ, etaṃ sāraṃ etaṃ pariyosānan”ti.
mn29:7.3.eng: that is the goal of the spiritual life, the core and the final end.”

mn29:7.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn29:7.5.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn29:7.5.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
